body.p: Over 1040 delegates converged on Hobart’s scenic harbour for the RANZCP’s 47th annual Congress from 20 to 24 May 2012 at the Grand Chancellor Hotel. With a theme of ‘Cells, Circuits and Syndromes’, the Congress covered mental health across the ages from birth to old age and across specialties, disorders and cultures.
Internationally eminent keynote speakers presented on a diverse range of mental health issues and included:

Professor Edward Bullmore, Clinical Director of the Behavioural and Clinical Neuroscience Institute at the University of Cambridge, Director of Research and Development for Cambridgeshire and Peterborough Foundation NHS Trust, Head of GlaxoSmithKline Clinical Unit in Cambridge and expert in human brain networks and connectivity.

p.italic: Presentation: The connectome: What’s in it for psychiatry?

body.p: Professor Ulrik Malt, Director Department of Neuropsychiatry and Psychosomatic Medicine at Oslo University Hospital and Professor of Medicine at University of Oslo, with expertise in traumatic stress, psychosomatic medicine, psychopharmacology and mood disorders.

p.italic: Presentation: The many faces of bipolar spectrum disorders

body.p: Professor Robert Ursano, Professor of Psychiatry and Neuroscience and Chair of the Department of Psychiatry at the Uniformed Services University of the Health Sciences, Bethesda, Maryland, Director of Center for the Study of Traumatic Stress, and specialist in post-traumatic stress disorder and public health planning for the psychological effects of terrorism and traumatic events.

p.italic: Presentation: Post-traumatic stress disorder and other trauma related disorders: Epidemiology, intervention, treatment and planning

body.p: Professor Trevor Young, Chair Department of Psychiatry, University of Toronto and renowned expert in mood disorders.

p.italic: Presentation: Mood, energy and neurobiology and bipolar disorder

body.p: Professor Mark Solms, Chair of Neuropsychology at the University of Cape Town and specialist in forebrain mechanisms of dreaming and psychoanalytic methods and theories in neuroscience.

p.italic: Presentation: Is psychoanalysis scientifically viable? The example of dream theory

body.p: Associate Professor Frances Thomson-Salo, expert in psychoanalysis and Associate Researcher at Murdoch Children’s Research Institute, works at the Royal Children’s and Women’s Hospitals in Melbourne, teaches infant observation on the University of Melbourne Graduate Diploma of Infant and Parent Mental Health and has published on infant and child psychotherapy.

p.italic: Presentation: Cells, circuits and consequences: Keeping the baby in mind

caption.p: Keynote speaker Associate Professor Frances Thomson-Salo

body.p: Professor Michael Berk, Chair of Psychiatry in the School of Medicine at Deakin University, Professorial Research Fellow at the University of Melbourne Department of Psychiatry and the Centre for Youth Mental Health and the Mental Health Research Institute, leader of the bipolar program at Orygen Youth Health, and expert in mood and psychotic disorders.

p.italic: Presentation: Oxidative and immune biomarkers as targets for the development of novel therapies

body.p: Professor Gerard Byrne, Head of the Discipline of Psychiatry, School of Medicine, University of Queensland, Director of Geriatric Psychiatry at the Royal Brisbane and Women’s Hospital and expert in Alzheimer’s disease.

The spectacular Museum of Old and New Art was the scene of one of the most highly attended welcome receptions in the College’s history. 750 guests roamed the museum, being stimulated by both confronting and beautiful art while socialising and catching up with colleagues.

caption.p: Welcome Reception at the Museum of Old and New Art

body.p: The Governor of Tasmania His Excellency The Honourable Peter Underwood opened the Congress following a welcome to country by Ms Cheryl Mundy to start a Congress filled with sessions and topics to suit all interests.

caption.p: The Governor of Tasmania His Excellency The Honourable Peter Underwood opens the Congress

body.p: At the College Ceremony, Professor Gavin Andrews provided a stimulating College Address which touched on the benefits and usefulness of psychiatry to inspire new psychiatrists, and those long in the profession, about the value of their work.

caption.p: Professor Gavin Andrews gives the College Address at the College Ceremony

body.p: New Fellows and Advanced Training Certificates recipients were presented at the Ceremony for successful completion of their studies. College Awards to acknowledge outstanding achievement to the community, psychiatry and mental health were presented to the following for their contributions to the College and mental health:
The College Medal of Honour – Dr Ian Holland Martin
The College Citation – The Honourable Justice William Carter QC and Professor Daniel O’Connor
The Ian Simpson Award – Dr Frances Dark
The Maddison Medallion – Dr Kelly McKenna-Kerr
The MSD Senior Research Award – Professor Gerard Byrne and Professor Michael Berk
The MSD Young Psychiatrist Award – Dr Brian Power
The Mark Sheldon Prize – Dr Michael Duke
The Addiction Psychiatry Prize – Dr Catherine Llewellyn
The Section of Psychotherapy Essay Prize – Dr Julia Jamaludin
The Medlicott Award – Dr Claire Wolfenden
The Howard Cooper Travelling Fellowship in Child and Adolescent Psychiatry – Dr Sasitorn Chantaratin
The Connell Werry Prize – Dr Julia Moore

The Committee for Research awarded the Congress Trainee Presentation Award to Dr Rebecca Wood for her presentation ’Self inflicted burns injuries in the Australian context’ for the best presentation by a trainee psychiatrist at this year’s Congress.
A highlight of the Congress was the world premiere performance of a piano sonata titled Psychsonata by Mr Michael Kieran Harvey, which was especially commissioned to celebrate the Congress.

caption.p: Mr Michael Kieran Harvey performs Psychsonata

body.p: The College’s annual general meeting was held on 23 May 2012 to hear the general business of the College.

A nautical themed Gala Dinner at Princes Wharf 1, complete with a presentation from Associate Professor Natasha Cica, author of Pedder Dreaming, and dancing into the night capped off an engaging Congress.

Thank you to Congress Convenor Professor Saxby Pridmore, Scientific Program Committee Chair Professor Mark Oakley Browne and Co-chair Professor Ken Kirkby and the whole Organising Committee for staging a wonderful event.

RANZCP Congress 2013 will be held in Sydney from 26–30 May 2013 with a theme of ‘Achievements and Aspirations’ and promises to be an exciting event, as it also celebrates the 50th anniversary of the College. More information is available at: www.ranzcp2013.com
